citations.narrative:
Forty-three rhesus macaques escaped from an outdoor primary enclosure due to the points of entry not remaining secure
during routine husbandry duties. On November 6, 2024, a group of caretakers were performing daily tasks in their
assigned areas. The caretaker assigned to this primary enclosure exited the enclosure to retrieve additional cleaning
equipment. During this time, forty-three of the fifty-three rhesus macaques housed therein escaped. Though the employee
reported to the facility’s Colony Management they had secured the backup door prior to leaving the enclosure, they could
not confirm if they locked the doors exclusive for staff entry. Further evaluation of the enclosure showed that the security
measures present were adequate, suggesting the housing facilities protocol had not been followed by the caretaker while
handling the animals. While the facility has recovered thirty-nine of the primates, four remain at large in the wooded area
adjacent to the facility.
When standard operating procedures put in place by the facility are not followed, the outcome can result in more
vulnerability to harm, injury, or increased health risks to the animals impacted or unaccounted for. All animal handling
shall be done as carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause physical harm or unnecessary discomfort.
Corrected by date of inspection on November 25, 2024 and to remain corrected from this date forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Jeffrey Shepherd, Assistant Director n
